questions.question: What is the basic objective of a cricket game?
questions.answer: The objective is to score more runs than the opposing team. Teams take turns batting and fielding.

questions.question: How many players are on each team in a standard cricket match?
questions.answer: Each team has 11 players.

questions.question: What is the length of a standard cricket pitch?
questions.answer: The pitch is 22 yards (20.12 meters) long.

questions.question: What are the three main formats of international cricket?
questions.answer: Test matches, One Day Internationals (ODIs), and Twenty20 (T20) Internationals.

questions.question: How many overs are there in a standard One Day International (ODI) match?
questions.answer: Each team bowls 50 overs in an ODI match.

questions.question: What is a hat-trick in cricket?
questions.answer: A hat-trick occurs when a bowler takes three wickets with three consecutive deliveries.

questions.question: What are the two main types of bowlers in cricket?
questions.answer: Fast bowlers and spin bowlers.

questions.question: What does the term 'duck' mean in cricket?
questions.answer: A 'duck' refers to a batsman getting out without scoring any runs.

questions.question: What is the role of a 'wicketkeeper'?
questions.answer: The wicketkeeper stands behind the stumps and is responsible for catching balls that pass the batsman and for stumping out batsmen.

questions.question: What is the difference between a 'wide' and a 'no-ball'?
questions.answer: A 'wide' is a delivery that is too far off for the batsman to reach, while a 'no-ball' is an illegal delivery due to various reasons such as overstepping the crease or high bouncing.

questions.question: How many runs are awarded for hitting the ball over the boundary without it touching the ground?
questions.answer: Four runs.

questions.question: What does 'LBW' stand for, and what does it mean?
questions.answer: 'LBW' stands for 'Leg Before Wicket.' It means the batsman is out because the ball hit their leg and would have gone on to hit the stumps.

questions.question: Which country won the first Cricket World Cup?
questions.answer: England won the first Cricket World Cup in 1975.

questions.question: What is the name of the area where the bowler delivers the ball to the batsman?
questions.answer: The 'delivery' or 'bowling crease' area.

questions.question: Who is considered one of the greatest Test batsmen of all time, known for his record of 100 international centuries?
questions.answer: Sachin Tendulkar.

questions.question: What is a 'boundary' in cricket?
questions.answer: A boundary is when the ball is hit to the edge of the field, either along the ground for four runs or in the air for six runs.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the 'third umpire'?
questions.answer: The third umpire assists the on-field umpires by reviewing decisions using video technology.

questions.question: What is the term for a match that ends without a result?
questions.answer: A 'draw' or 'no result' (in limited-overs cricket).

questions.question: Who is known for the famous 'underarm bowling' incident in cricket history?
questions.answer: Australiaâ€™s Dennis Lillee during a match against New Zealand in 1981.

questions.question: What is the name of the tournament contested by the top international teams every two years?
questions.answer: The ICC World Test Championship (for Test cricket) or the ICC Cricket World Cup (for ODIs).

questions.question: What is the term for a cricket match where both innings are not completed due to time constraints?
questions.answer: A 'draw'.

questions.question: Which country is known for having won the most ICC T20 World Cup titles?
questions.answer: West Indies, with two titles (2012 and 2016).

questions.question: What is a 'no-ball' in cricket?
questions.answer: A 'no-ball' is an illegal delivery due to the bowler's foot being over the crease, among other reasons.

questions.question: Who holds the record for the most runs in a single ODI match?
questions.answer: Rohit Sharma, with 264 runs.

questions.question: What is the name of the fielding position located directly behind the batsman, on the off-side?
questions.answer: Slip.

questions.question: In cricket, what does the term 'economy rate' refer to?
questions.answer: The average number of runs conceded per over bowled.

questions.question: What is the term for a bowler who is used specifically to bowl in the final overs of a limited-overs match?
questions.answer: Death bowler.

questions.question: Who was the captain of the Indian cricket team that won the 1983 World Cup?
questions.answer: Kapil Dev.

questions.question: What is the name of the award given to the player of the match in international cricket?
questions.answer: The 'Player of the Match' award.

questions.question: Which cricket ground is known as 'The Home of Cricket'?
questions.answer: Lord's Cricket Ground in London.

questions.question: What does 'follow-on' mean in Test cricket?
questions.answer: When the team batting first leads by a certain number of runs, the opposing team is asked to bat again immediately after their first innings.

questions.question: What is the name of the cricketing term used for a score of 50 runs?
questions.answer: A 'half-century'.

questions.question: Who is known as 'The Little Master' in cricket?
questions.answer: Sunil Gavaskar.

questions.question: What is a 'sixer' in cricket?
questions.answer: Hitting the ball out of the boundary on the full, which scores six runs.

questions.question: Which cricketer is famous for the 'Ball of the Century' delivered to Mike Gatting?
questions.answer: Shane Warne.

questions.question: What is the maximum number of overs a bowler can bowl in a T20 match?
questions.answer: Four overs.

questions.question: What term is used for a delivery that spins away from the batsman?
questions.answer: Off-spin.

questions.question: Who is the only cricketer to have scored 200 runs in a single ODI match and also take 5 wickets in an ODI match?
questions.answer: Chris Gayle.

questions.question: What does 'Duckworth-Lewis' refer to in cricket?
questions.answer: A method used to calculate target scores in rain-affected limited-overs matches.

questions.question: Who was the first player to reach 10,000 runs in ODIs?
questions.answer: Sourav Ganguly.
